speech.para: No doubt, I shall be quite in order in discussing the duties on tobacco. This matter is looked upon by many persons in Australia as one of paramount importance. The present position of the industry is rather extraordinary, because it is evident, from past events, that the report of the Tariff Board was based, not on deliberately false information, but on wrong premises. This was- recognized recently by the Prime Minister on his visit to Queensland. Tobacco leaf was grown in Australia more than 75 years ago. For the four years ended the 30th June, 1914, the average annual production of leaf was 2,300,000 lb. It will be seen that the production at that time was comparatively insignificant. Practically no expansion of the industry was noted until a few years ago; and we may well ask the reason for the phenomenal expansion that has taken place since 1929. The average annual production for the 10 years ended the 30th June, 1929, was slightly under 2,000,000 lb., as against the total requirement of 23,000,000 lb. per annum. During that period, the tobacco-growers in Australia were protected by a duty under the customs tariff amounting to about 2s. per lb. An attempt has been made by that section of the Senate which represents the Labour party to raise the import duty to 5s. 2d. per lb. I refuse to agree to that proposal as I believe in the scaling down of the fiscal wall. I propose to refer to the increases that have been made since the 22nd August, 1929, in the duty imposed under the customs tariff on unmanufactured tobacco entered to be locally manufactured into tobacco or cigarettes. These increases, although only proposals, and subject to ratification by Parliament, actually operated. The collection of duties under the various tariff resolutions has been validated up to and including the 29th February, 1932. The first resolution under the Customs Tariff 1921-28, which was tabled on the 22nd August, 1929, provided for a duty of 2s. per lb. Up to the 22nd of October, 1929, the duty was 2s. 5d. per lb. On the 21st November, 1929, it was increased to 3s. Until then, there had been no phenomenal expansion of the tobacco industry, as is shown in the Tariff Board report. On the 9th of July, 1930, the duty was increased to 3s. 6d. per lb., and on the 3rd of December, 1930, to 5s. 2d. per lb. During the two years from 1929 onwards, there was a great expansion of the tobacco growing industry. If this expansion was due to the high duties, there is surely a moral obligation on the Government to protect the interests of the thousands of growers who entered the industry as a result of the encouragement offered. When the present Government came into office, it acted on a Tariff Board report recommending the reduction of the import duty from 5s. 2d. to 3s. per lb. I do not object to the duty being reduced, because I 'believe that high duties are uneconomic, and the ultimate effect of the higher duty would have been to raise the price of Australian tobacco. The mistake was made in increasing the excise duty on manufactured tobacco at the same time. Before the alteration of the Scullin tariff, the excise duty on all tobacco manufactured in Australia was 2s. 4d. per lb., and it has now been increased to 4s. 6d. Under tha Scullin Government, the duty on imported tobacco was 5s. 2d. per lb., and the excise duty on tobacco manufactured in Australia was 2s. 4d. per lb., which brought the total charges on foreign tobacco up to 7s. 6d. per lb. When the present Government came into office, it reduced the duty on imported tobacco to 3s. per lb., and increased the excise on tobacco manufactured in Australia to 4s. 6d. Therefore, the total impost on foreign tobacco was still 7s. 6d. per lb.; but the excise duty on Australian tobacco was increased from 2s. 4d. to 4s. 6d., an increase of 93 per cent. What chance has the local" industry of holding its own against foreign competition when such a crushing burden is laid upon it? When the duty on imported tobacco was increased to 5s. 2d. per lb., the industry expanded in Australia, with the result that the number of growers increased from 660 to 4,764; so that the duties closely affect the livelihood of 4,764 families. The new growers, for the most part, were not experienced men; many of them were men who had lost their employment owing to the depression, and, with the few pounds left to them, were trying to make a living by growing tobacco. They have built up an equity in their property, and have accumulated knowledge about the cultivation and curing of tobacco leaf. Now those assets are jeopardized by the policy of the Government, because local production must inevitably be discouraged by the heavy increase of the excise duty.

The cash value of the Australian tobacco crop last year was £1,250,000, as compared with £92,000 for the previous year. It is surely to our advantage to develop an industry when it means that our importations from the United States of America will be correspondingly reduced. Most of the tobacco we import comes from the United States of America, a country with which we already have a heavy adverse trade balance. In Australian currency, our imports from the United States of America in 1929-30 were valued at £30,316,208, and our exports to that country at £5,233,772. In 1930-31, imports were valued at £12,867,833, and exports at £2,291,157. In the folio- lug year, the last for which figures are available, we: imported from the United States of America goods to the value of £8,966,579, and exported to that country goods valued at £4,096,410. The apparent increase in the volume of exports to the United States of America for 1931-32 was due V» the depreciation of Australian currency as compared with American currency. Our adverse trade balance with the United States of America over the last three years totals no less than £39,889,281. Even now we are growing only a small part of the tobacco consumed in Australia, and there is plenty of room for further expansion. Nevertheless, the Government, by its policy, has pronounced a sentence of death on the industry.

One of the outstanding features pf the Tariff Board's report is the fear, expressed that the tobacco-growing industry may become so profitable that there will bo a rush of new growers to the industry, resulting in over-production. The Board, however, failed to take into consideration the uncertain nature of the crop. According to figures prepared by the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, the average crop for the last ten years has been 3,000,000 lb. Foi the last three years the average crop has been 6,000,000 lb., whereas last year's crop, on which the Tariff Board based its calculations, was 12,000,000 lb. Are honorable senators prepared to have the industry relapse into the condition obtaining in 1914? Now let us consider the coming crop: According to returns prepared by the department, the Tasmanian crop in 1932 was fair, but in 1933, though the area under cultivation was greater, a large part of the crop was lost through blue mould. In Western Australia there was a fair crop in 1932, but this year the yield has been greatly reduced owing to seasonal conditions. The Victorian crop last year was 4,500,000 lb., but this year it will not exceed 2,000,000 lb. owing to frost and mould. There was a good crop in New South Wale3 in 1932, but this year half the crop has been lost as a result of heavy frosts at Tumut and hailstorms at Tamworth. In Queensland, the 1932 crop amounted to 2,750,000 lb., while the 1933 crop will be smaller by at least 500,000 lb. The total crop for this year is estimated to be not more than 6,000,000 lb., which is only half the amount produced last year; yet thu growers are to be penalized by having the excise duty increased, by 93 per cent. No industry could survive that. I heard the Minister say the other day that it was the policy of the Government to encourage the tobacco industry, so that it would supply most of the leaf consumed in Australia. He spoke with pride of the assistance rendered to the local industry by the Council for Scientific and Industrial research, and the BritishAustralasian Tobacco Company, which had granted a subsidy for tobacco investigation. How, then, does he justify the Government's excise policy? Tobaccogrowers do not work under a 44-hour week award, but rise at dawn, and, in many instances, do not retire until midnight. Tobacco-growing is infinitely more arduous than dairying, because those engaged in it have no time for recreation or relaxation of any kind.

talk.start.para: - During the curing season they do not go to bed at all.

- That is so. I realize that the proposal which I intend to submit will be attacked by the Minister in charge of the bill on the ground that, if adopted, the revenue would be seriously 'affected. Although the surplus for the last financial year has been given as £3,500,000, the Government still says that it cannot reduce excise duties owing to revenue considerations. How does it know how to estimate its revenue for the present financial year? Quite recently it was stated that the Government could not finalize the budget until the World Economic Conference now sitting in London had concluded its deliberations. The Government admits that, in the circumstances now prevailing, it cannot calculate its actual expenditure for the present financial year, because it does not know how much to allocate for exchange, or for numerous other liabilities. In view of that decision, how can the Minister say that it is necessary to preserve revenue at the highwater mark to which the tobacco industry has brought it in the past financial year? The Government does not know what its expenditure will be. To attempt to forecast it is to work in the dark.

speech.para: The next important point which I wish to discuss is the amount of revenue which the Government is entitled to extract from the tobacco industry. If any industry in Australia contributes to Commonwealth taxation, its possibilities of expansion have a very important bearing on the revenue. That is of particular importance in this instance. In dealing with the revenue aspect of the subject, the Tariff Board stated -

quote.para: Having regard to all the circumstances, the Tariff Board is of the opinion that it -would be unwise, during the period in which the Australian leaf-growing industry is becoming established, to seek to increase the net revenue derived from tobacco beyond the amount raised during 1929-30, namely, approximately £0,500,000.

speech.para: The Tariff Board definitely stated that the tobacco-growing industry should not be discouraged, and that until it was firmly established the Government should not collect from it more than £6,500,000 in revenue. What has the Government taken from this industry, and has it observed the recommendations of the Tariff Board? If it has extracted more than the board recommends, the assumption is reasonable that it is responsible for discouraging the industry.

talk.start.para: - What is the date of the Tariff Board's report?

- The 3rd February, 1932. The average revenue collected from the tobacco industry over a period of eleven years was £5,500,000. In 1930-31 it was £6,500,000, which is the figure at which the Tariff Board said that it should remain until the industry was on a firm basis. In 1931-32, the amount collected increased from £6,500,000 in the previous year to £7,150,000, and in 1932-33 it was £7,312,988. The figures for the last year were made up by customs duties of £2,561,445 and excise duties of £4,751,543. On a percentage basis, it will be seen that the Government is collecting an unduly large proportion of its revenue from the tobacco industry in the form of excise and customs duties. Taking the revenue figures from 1921-22 - in that period the revenue was only £4,908,683, to the present day, we find that . the special taxation which the Government ha3 imposed upon the industry has increased by 50 per cent. In view of the Tariff Board's recommendation that the amount raised by excise should not exceed £6,500,000, can the Government justify its action? If the tobacco consumption remained as at present, we could assume that this burden is pressing unduly upon the people, but consumption has not remained stationary. For the same period, the consumption of tobacco dropped by 13 per cent., while the revenue collected increased by 50 per cent. The Government is therefore collecting in excise £750,000 more than the Tariff Board recommended as a fair amount. It is impossible for the industry to carry on profitably under these conditions. I have copies of the figures which I have carefully prepared, which I shall be willing to supply to any honorable senator interested in the subject. My figures are based on an Australian crop of 6,000,000" lb. for this year. I have not attempted to estimate the revenue from this source for next year or for the following year, but have estimated on a 6,000,000-lb. crop for this year. On these figures, the total amount of revenue which the Government will secure is £6,661,764. In committee, I propose to move for the imposition of differential rates of excise on Australian and imported tobacco. I submit the following statement showing differential rates of excise duty, with the object of tobacco based on an estimated Australian encouraging the growing of Australian crop of 6,000,000 lb. : -

speech.para: I know that the Minister will say that it would be difficult to administer such a scheme; but I shall show him how it can be effectively policed, and how, if adopted, would be of great benefit to Australian tobacco-growers. I am willing to supply the Minister with a copy of the table which I have just quoted, and I shall be glad if he can show me where it. is wrong, assuming, of course, that it is not the desire of the Government to extract more than £6,500,000 from the industry. If it is the desire of the Government to collect an exorbitant amount of revenue from this source it should say so, otherwise it will not be able to justify its action. If, for the reasons I have mentioned, the Government cannot calculate its. expenditure, bow can it estimate the additional revenue to be received from the tobacco industry? Doubtless it will be contended that it is udt possible successfully to police the proposal which 1 have outlined with regard to the excise duties; but to make the position clear, I remind the committee that the investigation of the industry in 1932 was not the first that had been made. In 1927, the Tariff Board conducted an inquiry into it, and recommended that assistance be given to the Australian growers by means of a preferential excise duty. It is reasonable to assume that, prior to making its recommendations, the board had considered carefully any difficulty that might arise from effect being given to its proposal, and was thoroughly satisfied that a preferential excise rate could be policed effectively. It had before it alternative requests, namely, the payment of a bounty at the rate of 6d. per lb. on all marketable tobacco leaf grown in Australia, or a reduction of the excise duty on tobacco manufactured from leaf grown it Australia as against imported leaf, and came to this conclusion : -

quote.para: As regards the matter of reduction- of exciseduty, the main grounds advanced were that such reduction would enable tobacco manufacturers to pay growers higher prices for the leaf, and also to place tobacco manufactured from, or containing a proportion of, Australian leaf on the market at lower prices than those charged for tobacco made from imported leaf.

speech.para: After careful consideration had been given by the board to the requests in the light both of evidence tendered and of the information gained from other sources, the board reported -

quote.para: The board is of the opinion that the most satisfactory method would be by reducing the excise, with a special provision that any excise reduction be passed on to the grower.

speech.para: As I have observed, we may reasonably assume that the board had thoroughly investigated every possible difficulty that might 'be encountered by the Customs Department in policing the differential excise duty, and had satisfied itself that it could be administered. But, apparently, the government of the day gave heed to the representations of the manufacturers who had urged that to impose different excise duties would create difficulties for them. I admit that it would involve a certain amount of confusion ; but we have to remember that the interests of 4,000 growers are at stake. Therefore, we should do that which lies in our power to give them a reasonable chance of getting some return on their capital. Though there may be no legal obligation on the Government to assist our growers, there is certainly a moral obligation to do so, because so many of these men engaged in the industry in the full belief that governmental action to assist it would be reasonably stable. Now, unhappily, a considerable number are threatened with complete extinction.

On a -former occasion when these duties were under consideration in the Senate, I moved that this item be postponed for further consideration, after a complete investigation of the industry had been made. The Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) now admits that the tobacco-growers of Australia did not have full opportunity to present their case to the board. This admission was made 'by the right honorable gentleman during his recent visit to Queensland. In reply to a deputation at Mareeba, he said that there would be a further independent inquiry into the industry in that district. I do not wish to question the fairness of the Prime Minister in promising an investigation of the Mareeba position; but I should like to know why it is to be limited to one particular area. Why should it not also include Tumut, Tamworth, and the tobacco-growing districts in northern Victoria? Why should the promised investigation be restricted to the Mareeba district? Are we to infer that the right honorable gentleman's promise is in the nature of a political sop to the tobacco growers in that area ?

talk.start.para: - Order ! The honorable senator must confine his remarks to the item before the committee.

- I submit, Mr. Chairman, that if I can bring evidence to show that the recommendation of the Tariff Board to impose an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb. on tobacco made from Australian and foreign leaf was not the result of a complete and scientific investigation into the Australian industry, my remarks are relevant. I refer honorable senators to reports appearing in the June issue of Tobacco, the official organ of the Australian Tobacco-Growers Association. Dealing with the visit of the Prime Minister to Mareeba, that journal states that Mr. S. Birrell, the President of the North Queensland Tobacco-Growers Association, in introducing a deputation to the Prime Minister, said -

quote.para: The Federal Government, in altering tha tariff duty, was guided by the Tariff Board; but the board did not come near Mareeba to inquire, nor were local growers given a chance of putting their case.

speech.para: Every one knows that the Tariff Board gave the Mareeba growers only 27 hours' notice of its intention to make an investigation the result of which would so vitally affect their future operations. At Townsville, two days after his visit to Mareeba, Mr. Lyons, replying to requests made by a deputation of local growers, said -

quote.para: What he had promised to the growers at Mareeba was a special investigation into the aspect affecting them, particularly because they had not had an opportunity to place evidence before the Tariff Board when it inquired into the Australian tobacco industry. He added, " I do not propose that this inquiry should extend beyond this special case of Mareeba ".

speech.para: If, for the reasons given, a special investigation is to he made in the case of the Mareeba growers, surely if it can be shown that growers in other areas were under the same disability, the proposed inquiry should be national in extent.

talk.start.para: - What chance did the growers in Western Australia have to place their position before the board?
- None whatever. Tobacco further reports the Prime Minister as saying at Mareeba -

quote.para: If what was said were true, it seemed to him that there was only one thing to do. It was right that the board should investigate the question on the spot in order to get at the facts connected with the industry.

speech.para: Let me now recapitulate my arguments. I have shown (1) that an import duty of 5s. 2d. was imposed by the Scullin Government, and that, as a result of the encouragement thus given, the number of tobacco-growers in Australia increased from 600 to over 4,000; (2) that the production of leaf last year amounted to 12,000,000 lb., and that this season's production will be in the vicinity of about 6,000,000 lb.; (3) that, although the Tariff Board has expressed the opinion that the' revenue from tobacco duties should not exceed £6,500,000, the Government's proposals will increase the revenue to £7,360,000, representing an increase of 50 per cent over the figures for 1931; (4) that a preferential excise duty of 3s. per lb. on tobacco manufactured from Australian leaf, as recommended by the Tariff Board in 1927, will produce a revenue of approximately £6,500,000; and give to the industry the protection it requires. Finally, I have shown that even the Prime Minister himself has admitted that the Tariff Board did not give tobacco growers an adequate opportunity to present their case. Why should this section of our primary producers be denied a fighting chance to succeed? If the Government adheres to its present intention with regard to these duties, it will deal a death blow to the tobacco-growing industry in Australia, and it is my intention, at the proper time, to take whatever action is possible in this chamber to save the industry. If I, and those who support me in this matter, are unsuccessful, there will be only one course to pursue, and that is to go to the tobacco-growing districts and tell the people concerned precisely what has been done in this chamber. If the Government does not accept proposals which we intend to put before the committee at a later stage, the only conclusion we can come to' is it does not desire to see this important Australian primary industry expand, and the people engaged in it prosper.

talk.start.para: .- Desiring to get away from the smoky atmosphere associated with tobacco duties, I invite honorable senators to give consideration to the Government's proposals concerning beer. The brewing industry is of paramount importance, considered from the point of view of revenue. Within the last few days we have been told that the anticipated surplus for the year will be about £3,500,000, and that it is the intention of the Government to give relief from taxation to certain sections of the people. Surely it is time that the consumers, including those who have a predilection for liquid refreshment, had some consideration. The brewing industry in Australia is a very important one, having extremely wide ramifications. It is of considerable importance, as it provides employment and revenue. A great number of hands is directly employed in it, including skilled tradesmen in various branches of engineering, coopers, motor drivers and others. The business employs an extensive administrative and selling staff. A great deal of employment is also given in secondary and allied trades, such as in the manufacture of bottles, the use of timber, and the manufacture of barrels, cases and crates, crown corks, printing for advertising and labels, motor and horse-drawn vehicles and their equipment, the provision of coal and electricity, and the manufacture of machinery and plant. In addition, there are associated with the industry many primary industries that grow the raw materials used in the production of beer, such as barley, hops, sugar, straw for envelopes, and other materials. In view of the fact that primary production is at a very low ebb in Australia to-day, some relief should be given to this industry. Any assistance that it receives would react to the benefit of those who are engaged in the hop, timber, and sugar industries. In committee, I shall move that the House of Representatives be requested to make the duties, sub-items a and b, ls. 4d. a gallon. I am confident that any revenue lost by the reduction of 8d. a gallon would be made good by the greater demand caused by the lowering of the price of beer, an undertaking to lower it having been given by the brewers. The excise duty has been increased by 700 per cent, since 1914, and now amounts to 3d. a pint.
- It is a pity that people buy beer.

- If they did not, the Queensland sugar industry, which is strongly protected, would suffer. I have no wish to parade my virtues, but all my life I have been a total abstainer from liquor and tobacco. I am asking for this relief, not as a prohibitionist, but as one who wishes to help the industry. Beer is 100 per cent. Australian-made. The high taxation imposed is having an injurious effect on several industries, including the sugar and hop industries. Hops are .grown in Tasmania, and in the Goulburn Valley of Victoria. My sympathies are with the men who follow this occupation, because they are in a precarious position. Not long ago, I passed through the Derwent Valley in Tasmania, where thousands of pounds have been invested in the hop industry, and found that the farmers there were taking on the cultivation of tobacco in the hope that they might regain some of the prosperity that they formerly enjoyed; but in their new venture also they have met with misfortune, because blue mould, which is rampant in the Derwent Valley, has practically destroyed their crops. A reasonable reduction of the excise duty on beer would result in the price of it being reduced. Its consumption would then increase, and more employment would be provided. The duty on beer was reduced recently in England by one penny a pint, and, as a result, the consumption immediately increased. Viscount Snowden was Chancellor of the Exchequer when the reduction was made. In introducing the proposal, he said that it would assist towards the general rehabilitation of trade and commerce in England, and that the revenue would benefit from the resultant greater consumption. That is what happened. The increased consumption of beer in England has meant more work in breweries and hotels, as well as in allied industries. High taxation of the liquor trade is a form of prohibition, because, on account of the existing prices, due to the heavy duties, liquor is passing beyond the reach of the average wage-earner. The output of beer in Australia for the year ended the 30th June, 1928, was 74,663,722 gallons, but at the end of June, 1932, it had fallen to 47,670,490 gallons, a reduction of about 40 per cent. If the high price of 9d. a pint in the capital cities is maintained, the consumption of beer will continue to decline. The serious effect which the high duties have on the brewing industry must be realized. Over 40,000,000 fewer beer bottles are being used in Australia as a result, of the enormous reduction in consumption. In New South "Wales alone the reduction in the number of bottles in. 1932, compared with 1930, was 17,500,000, while in Victoria it was about 14,000,000. This has meant a vast restriction of employment. Those engaged in the manufacture of cases and crates have also been most adversely affected. In New South "Wales, in 1932, the cases made were 106,306 fewer than in 1930. In 1929, primary products to the following extent were used in the manufacture of beer in Australia: Malt,' 2,437,600 bushels; hops, 2,343,012 lb.; sugar, 34,191,808 lb. Owing to the decline in the consumption of beer, there was a huge drop in the use of those commodities in 1931, amounting to 10,000,000 lb. in the case of sugar alone, the figures for that year being, malt, 1,798,573 bushels; hops, 1,699,827 lb.; sugar, 24,503,024 lb. Can one wonder at State Governments finding it difficult to balance their budgets? The official figures for 1932 show that, so far as primary products are concerned, the position became considerably worse. In that year the decline in the use of sugar had increased to over 13,000,000 lb., while the quantity of hops used was down by 924,039 lb., and malt by 905,827 bushels, the figures being: Malt, 1,531,773 bushels; hops, 1,418,973 lb.; and sugar, 21,092,176 lb. High taxation has been largely responsible for the huge decline in the demand for bottles, cases, crates, and the ' primary products used in the manufacture of beer.

speech.para: In normal times, the excise duty on beer returned in revenue to the Federal Government £6,190,725. It is believed that a reduction of excise duty by from8d. to1s. a gallon, combined with a reduction in the retail prices, would result in a greatly increased consumption, and consequently the collection of additional revenue by the Treasury. It would also mean a more extensive use of barley, hops and sugar, and in additional employment in the making of bottles, barrels, cases, and crates.

Statistics covering the period during which the excise tariff on beer has been increased from 3d. to 2s. a gallon, an increase of 700 per cent., reveal that the increase of revenue to the Commonwealth practically corresponds with the increase of duty until the year 1928-29, which was the peak of beer excise revenue. In that year, it reached £6,190,725, at 2s. a gallon, being an increase of 681 per cent, over the figures for 1913-14, when the rate was 3d. a gallon. Since 1928-29, the revenue has declined, and for the year ended the 30th June last, it 'had fallen to £4,767,049, disclosing a drop of 30 per cent, in three years. Honorable senators have said a good deal about the desirability of assisting primary and secondary industries. Here is a chance to give practical help to both, by stimulating the sales of malt, barley, hops, timber, and sugar, and the manufacture of engines, casks, and cases.' I commend my request to the favorable consideration of the Senate.

talk.start.para: . - There are two outstanding items which are dealt with under the excise which contribute to the comfort and enjoyment of the average Australian citizen - tobacco and beer. Senator Hardy has dealt with the tobacco position most extensively, and I am in accord with his remarks generally on the subject.

speech.para: I desire now to deal with the important subject of beer, and urge the Government to reduce the excise on that product so that the public may be enabled to buy it. I am convinced that only by a reduction in the rate of excise on beer can this most palatable beverage be restored to the tables of the people. Senator Dunn has moved a request that the excise should be reduced by 8d. a gallon, and the public would be most thankful if the Government acceded to the request. I hope that there will be a reduction of excise of at least 6d. a gallon, an amount which could easily be passed on. The present rate ofexcise is 2s. a gallon, or 4d. a bottle, and a reduction of 6d. a gallon would make it possible to reduce the beer by1d. a bottle.

It must be remembered that, in addition to the excessive federal excise of 4d. a bottle on beer, the State Governments also tax this and other liquors heavily. In most States, the licensing fees for hotels are heavy, and are paid in lump sums, and, in addition, varying amounts, which sometimes reach 7 per cent., are collected by the State Government on liquor purchases. It will be seen, therefore, that intoxicating liquors, and particularly beer, are subject to exceptionally heavy taxation. It would almost appear that the Federal and State Governments were endeavouring to bring about prohibition by taxation, a policy to which I am entirely opposed. Ministers in the Senate recently made the satisfactory statement that the Government was considering the desirability of reducing the rates of duty on Scotch whisky in order to obtain from this source a greater revenue as a result of increased imports. The Australian public read that statement, and were pleased; but they are asking why even greater relief should not be given to the community by reducing the rates on beer which is manufactured in the Commonwealth entirely from Australian products. The Government must have noticed the reduced consumption of beer as shown by the customs and excise figures, and I am of the opinion that, unless something is done in the direction of granting a reduction in excise duty, that downward drift will most assuredly continue.

For some considerable time there has been a definite demand throughout Australia for cheaper beer. The consumer contends that wages, rents, and interest have been reduced, in addition to the price of foodstuffs and wearing apparel, and, quite naturally, he asks when the price of beer is going to be reduced. The price of this commodity to the public has always been regulated by the amount of excise duty; in other words, all increases in the price of beer have been made a3 a result of increases in the excise duty, and it is impossible to reduce the price of this article, to fall into line with the reduced spending power of the people, until such time as a reasonable reduction is obtained in the excise duty. Ministers talk a good deal about the Premiers plan, and the Government having reduced pensions and the wages of civil servants by approximately 22-J per cent. ; but I have yet to find that it has reduced charges on products such as beer by any amount at all. If the spending public is to reap any benefit under the Premiers plan, it is time that the Government reduced its taxation by 22£ per cent, in every direction, including excise. I know of nothing that would create more employment than a reduction of the burden of federal taxation.

I am assured that the Licensed Victuallers Association of New South Wales has approached the Commonwealth Government, and has stated that it has no desire to gain any additional profit from the reduction of the excise duty; that it has given the Prime Minister (My. Lyons) a specific undertaking that any such reduction will be passed on to the consuming public. A similar assurance has been given by the producers of Australian whisky. Some persons do not drink intoxicating liquors to-day, because they cannot afford to do so on account of their reduced earnings. A reduction in price would again bring these beverages within the . reach of the people, which would result in increased sales.
The following official figures will show the extent to which the consumption of beer has fallen off in Australia: -
Those figures disclose a reduction of approximately 40 per cent, for the year ended June, 1932, as compared with that ended June, 1928.-' I have not been able to obtain figures for the current year.

talk.start.para: - They show a material increase in consumption.

- That ia excellent news; but, at the same time, I am confident that, if the Government wishes the revenue again to become normal, it must reduce the rate of excise as was done with marked success from a revenue aspect in Great Britain. It must not be forgotten that the reduction in the consumption of beer has a serious effect upon the primary producer, as the commodities used in the manufacture of this article are products of the Australian soil. Comparing the years 1927 and 1932, the decrease in the consumption was: malt, 905,827 bushels; hops, 924,039 lb.; and sugar, 13,099,632 lb. The reduction in the use of beer also has a serious effect upon subsidiary and associated industries, and upon the revenue of the railways department, as the quantity of beer forwarded to country centres has declined alarmingly, and it i3 a commodity upon which the very highest rates of freights are charged. At present many hotels are working with skeleton staffs during the major portion of the week, relying on the employment of casual labour at the week-end, when the only reasonable volume of business is done. They have been forced to do this because their business does not warrant the employment of what was in former years a normal number of employees. By increasing the volume of business, the hotelkeeper will, of necessity, have to increase his staff to cope with it.

speech.para: The only solution of the existing drift in the consumption of beer is the reduction in its price to the consumer to bring this into line with his reduced spending power, and that can be achieved only by a substantial lowering of the existing excise duties. Such a course would mean an increase, and not a decrease, of the revenue, because of the greater amount of beer that would be consumed. This was proved in Great Britain recently.

talk.start.para: [11.59]. - There are one or two major considerations which I desire to mention, and which honorable senators should keep definitely in mind when dealing with this measure in committee. Two main objectives must be kept definitely in view. First, there is the collection of revenue,, which, from the point of view of a.

speech.para: Treasurer, is a matter of considerable importance; the other is that any alteration of the excise duty has a material effect on the measure of protection given to the Australian industry concerned. The two things definitely exist; but they are quite distinct. We cannot alter the excise duties without either increasing or decreasing the measure of protection given to the industry concerned, unless there is a corresponding addition to, or deduction, from the customs revenue. I do not know whether Senator Johnston, who is the greatest advocate of freetrade in this chamber, has considered that aspect of the subject.

talk.start.para: - I have.

- Does the honorable senator desire a greater measure of protection to the Australian tobacco-growing industry? Only yesterday I heard the honorable senator say that not once during the tariff debate had he voted for a higher duty, and that in no circumstances would he do so. I submit that he cannot vote for a lower excise duty on tobacco, beer, or whisky, without voting for a higher measure of protection to the industry concerned. '
- I voted for lower charges to the consumers.

- The position definitely is that the honorable senator proposes to vote for the collection of less revenue, and also, in the case of the three commodities which I have mentioned, for a greater measure of protection. I want the honorable senator to realize what he is doing. Ho says that he will never vote for a higher duty or for a greater measure of protection, and then he tells us that he proposes to do the thing which he says he will not do. The honorable senator also said something about the continuous diminution of the revenue from beer. That is not a fact, because last year the revenue from the excise on beer was greater than in the previous year. The consumption of beer is on the up-grade; last year's consumption exceeded that of the preceding year by about 1,000,000 gallons. While I do not dispute that the increase of the price of beer has definitely affected consumption, I do say that we have passed the trough of the depression ; things are gradually improving, and, consequently, we oan 'expect a gradual increase of the revenue from dutiable goods. The purchasing power of the community as a whole is greater than it was several months ago. When a Treasurer 'sets himself the task of collecting a certain amount of revenue from various sources, including excise, that revenue must be obtained if at all possible. Honorable senators have only to study the sources of the Government's revenue, and the channels of expenditure, to realize that a government which has set out to obtain a certain sum by way of revenue has not much left after it has met its interest bill, repatriation obligations, invalid and old age pension commitments, and has made payments to the States. Leaving out of our consideration for the moment the revenue and expenditure of the Post Office - a department which, more or less, pays its own way - we find that, apart from the expenditure on defence, there are only a few million pounds left with which to come and go. A certain sum must be obtained each year from excise duties, which, I submit, is a legitimate source of revenue; it has always been so regarded in every country in the world. The main thing is so to adjust the levying of duties as to get the best results. I am not in a position to say what the final view of the Government on these subjects will be; I only know that it must obtain a certain, revenue each year. It is the Government's duty to dev.ise means for obtaining that revenue. < Three suggestions have been made this morning. Senator Hardy asked for a reduction of ls. 6d. per lb. on the excise on tobacco leaf; Senator Dunn sought a reduction of 8d. a gallon in the excise on beer; Senator Johnston, who would have been satisfied with a reduction of 6d. a gallon in the case of beer, suggested a reduction of 5s. a gallon on Australian whisky.
- What about rum?
- He did not mention rum. On the basis of last year's consumption of beer in Australia, the proposed reduction of the duty would result in a loss of £1,622,615 on that one item alone.

speech.para: Honorable senators will agree that that is a fairly substantial sum. I take it that the only purpose of Senator Hardy's proposal for the reduction of the excise on Australian tobacco leaf is to increase the consumption of Australian leaf. The honorable senator is seeking a greater measure of protection to the growers of tobacco leaf in this country; he wants to see a greater consumption of the locallyproduced tobacco. If his suggestion were given effect, the loss of revenue from that source might easily amount to £1,036,174 a year. Compared with those losses, Senator Johnston's suggestion for a reduction of 5s. a gallon in the excise duty on whisky appears quite moderate, for it represents only about £33,629. Together, however, the three items would bring in £2,692,418 less revenue, if reduced as suggested.

talk.start.para: - Assuming that there would be no increased consumption.

- I ask honorable senators to look at this matter from the stand-point of a Minister who is asked to make a recommendation to Cabinet. Having in mind the«heavy burden of taxation, would they recommend a reduction of the excise duty as the best way of helping their country in its time of difficulty?
- The Minister will admit that the suggestions were both reasonable and just.

- Would Senator Hardy handle Australia's finances in that way? I say definitely that if the revenue from excise were reduced by £2,692,418, the Government would be crippled in its efforts to grant relief from other forms of taxation.
- Another government would probably adopt other methods.
- Will the Minister explain how next year's revenue and expenditure can be estimated seeing that it has postponed certain decisions in view of the happenings at the World Economic Conference ?

- I am not aware that the Government has done any such thing. I repeat that to grant the proposed requests would be to reduce the revenue to the extent which I have mentioned. That would mean that, of the surplus at the end of the financial year just completed, less than £1,000,000 would remain.
- The increased consumption would more than make up for the losses.
- It would not. I admit thai there would be some pick-up, but the amount would not in any way approach the losses.
- The experience of England in connexion with the duty on beer does not support the Minister's contention.

- In the circumstances, the Government feels that it must ask the Senate to leave it free to arrange its budget for the coming year in the way which it believes will be in the best interests of Australia. There will be another opportunity to discuss these matters when the budget proposals are before us. I cannot say now what the Government may decide to do, but I cannot envisage a position in which it would be either safe or desirable to budget for any appreciable reduction of the revenue received last year from excise. We all hope that when the Government brings down its budget, it may be able to afford to the Australian public a relief which will be really worth while, and materially assist in placing this country once more on the road to prosperity.

. - The Minister has put up an eloquent plea for the retention of the excessive duty on beer, and he has stated that even if the excise were reduced, there would be no appreciable increase of consumption. The experience in this and other countries is to the contrary, because practically in every instance in which the excise has been reduced on popular commodities, their consumption has largely increased, and the revenue has benefited considerably thereby. Every ingredient used in the making of beer in this country is an Australian product, and therefore, if we stimulate the consumption of beer by reducing the excise, we shall encourage subsidiary industries as well. The brewing of beer absorbs a considerable quantity of sugar. The figures for the year ending June, 1931, show that compared with the year ending

speech.para: June, 1929, there was a decrease in the production of sugar by over 13,000,000 lb., of malt by 90,000 bushels, and of hops by 924^000 lb.

talk.start.para: - It must not be forgotten that last year the sugar industry made a gift of £50,000 to the brewing -industry.

- It is clearly evident that Queensland senators are prepared to act in the interests only of their own State. By reducing the excise duty, we shall stimulate not only the beer industry, but also the hop, barley and sugar industries, with a consequent benefit to the Government by way of income and other taxation. As the excise on beer has increased, so has the quantity consumed decreased. Although the latest figures show that there has been an. increase in consumption, it is small indeed compared with ' the consumption a few years ago, when the price of beer was considerably lower than it is to-day. The figures supplied by the Minister show that in 1920, the consumption of beer was 69,000,000 gallons, whereas last year, it was 48,000,000 gallons. If it is the intention of the Government to bring about prohibition, it should make a straightout announcement to that effect and increase the excise to, say, 5s. a gallon. Very little profit is being made to-day by either the wholesale or retail sections of the trade, and so far as I can gather, many hotelkeepers are on the verge of bankruptcy..
- The Government is bringing about prohibition by taxation.

- That seems to be its intention. If the excise were lowered, I do not think that the Government would lose one penny of revenue as a result. The experience in Great Britain has been that reductions of excise have brought about increased revenue.
- The British Parliament reduced the excise on 'beer by Id. per pint.

- If the excise en beer were reduced, I am firmly convinced that the revenue from that source would be increased, and I shall, at the committee stage, vote for the amendment which has been foreshadowed by Senator Dunn. \

. - We should do everything within our power to encourage the tobacco industry, because there is every possibilitiy of its developing into a great Australian industry. Senator Hardy has put up a convincing case on behalf of the tobacco growers, who have already demonstrated that they can supply the Australian consumers with a tobacco equal to the imported article. The Government's tariff proposals will not, by any means, give the tobacco-growers the encouragement that they are entitled to expect from this National Parliament. Senator Hardy has clearly shown that if his proposal is agreed to, the Government will suffer no loss of revenue. Therefore, honorable senators should not hesitate to accept it.

speech.para: Beer, like tea, is a national beverage, because about 90 per cent, of the workers of this country indulge in it to a lesser or greater extent. It is produced in every country in the world, and is usually purchaseable at a price well within the capacity of the pockets of the people who do the hard work of the country. The Government is fearful that if the excise is reduced it will be faced with a loss of revenue. Our surplus revenue this year is estimated at £3,500,000. Since it has been stated that the Government wishes to spread that surplus over the population of Australia so as to give the greatest benefit to the greatest number of people, I suggest that by decreasing the excise as proposed by Senator Hardy relief will be spread over the greatest number of people who are in dire need of it. The production of beer throughout Australia for the year ended the 30th June, 1928, was 74,600,000 gallons, but at the end of June last year it had fallen to 47,600,000, or a reduction of 40 per cent. That falling off of production can be accounted for in many ways, but chiefly because of the unemployment of a vast number of our people, and their consequent incapacity to purchase beer at any price. The British Government by decreasing the excise on beer increased its revenue, and there is no reason why a reduction of excise in this country should not have a similar effect. It should be remembered that a number of primary products are used in the manufacture of beer. In 1929, the manufacturers took 2,437,600 bushels of malt, 2,343,012 lb. of hops, and 34.191.S08 lb. of sugar; but, in 1931, owing to the decline in the consumption of beer, there was a tremendous curtailment of the use of those products in the manufacture of beer, the figures being : Malt, 1,798,573 bushels; hops, 1,699,827 lb.; sugar, 24.503,024 lb. The reduction in the quantity of sugar used was nearly 10,000,000 lb.,' and, in 1932, the decline was over 13,000,000 lb. Although the Minister who represents the Treasury in this chamber claims that the present excise duties on beer and tobacco are required for revenue purposes, the Opposition contends that the revenue position would not be seriously affected by lowering them, because this would lead to an increase of the consumption of these commodities.

I find it difficult to obtain pipe tobacco made from leaf grown in Australia. Last Monday I inquired at a leading shop in my home town for the particular brand of Australian tobacco that I like, and was informed that it could not be obtained. I consider myself a connoisseur of tobacco, and I prefer the locally-grown article to any imported tobacco. The fact that tobacco made from, local leaf cannot be procured from a leading shop shows the stranglehold that the overseas interests have obtained upon an infant Australian industry. It would be in the interests of- the people of this country so to adjust the customs and excise tariffs as to increase the use of" tobacco made from Australian leaf.

A number of honorable senators on the Opposition side do not drink beer, but I am not one of them. The statistics show that the finances would not be so seriously affected as the Minister representing the Treasury would have us believe, by a reduction of the excise duties on beer. The figures submitted this morning by Senator Hardy were quite convincing as to the relief that would be given to the primary producers if the excise rates suggested by him were adopted. It is well known that probably 98 per cent, of the men employed on the waterfront enjoy a glass of beer at the end of a hard day's toil, and in using this national beverage, they are helping important sections of the primary producers. The Government, by its excise proposals, is not prepared to study the interests of those who do the arduous work of this country, including those who grow hops, sugar and barley; it prefers to use a portion of its surplus revenue to relieve from taxation those who conduct big businesses in Collins-street, Melbourne, and George-street, Sydney.

talk.start.para: .- The left wing of the Opposition has discharged its battery first, and at a suitable time for gaining the greatest publicity. The Leader of the Opposition, in charge of the right wing, has displayed much concern over the unfortunate primary producers; but I do not propose to reply at length to the observations that have been made. Sitting suspended from 12. J/5 to 2.15 p.m.

- We have been treated to some interesting observations from a double-headed political monstrosity, the Opposition in this chamber, as it is constituted to-day. I was astounded at the crocodile tears shed so liberally by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) over the plight of the primary producers. This is the gentleman who was a member of a government which imposed so high a tariff against the commodities used by the primary producers that it has ever since embarrassed the relations between the present Government with its erstwhile friends, the Country party. Senator Hardy rejoiced my heart by voicing the sentiment which I have been praying to hear from him during the last five or six weeks. He said that the high tariff placed on tobacco by the last Government imposed on the present Government the moral obligation to protect the interests of the industry. That is the principle which has' been our guide in dealing with tariff amendments. Many industries have sprung up under the protection of extraordinarily high duties, and the Government has had to take action to prevent a crash. I assure honorable senators that this moral responsibility has been recognized and accepted by the Government in its dealings with the tobacco industry.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition made one or two interesting statements. He said that we in Australia were producing tobacco equal to that produced anywhere else in the world. That is an exaggeration, and I speak as one who has taken a part in the production of tobacco. Then he said that Australian tobacco was put on the market at a cheaper price than imported tobacco. So it should, seeing that it enjoys protection to the extent of 300 per cent.

talk.start.para: - We also produce tobacco that is equal to the world's worst.

- Yes, in that respect we also excel. Senator Hardy described this as an industry of mushroom growth. That is true; but the growth has been due", not so much to the imposition of high duties by the Scullin Government, as to a realization by the people, after learning the result of expert investigations, that there was something to be made out of tobacco. Senator Hardy stated that, under an import duty of 2s. per lb., production in Australia was small, and that, when the duty was first increased to 3s. per lb., production did not materially increase. In view, however, of the fact that a period of only three months had elapsed - from August, 1929, to November, 1929 - no material increase could have been looked for. He sought to justify the import duty of 5s. 2d. per lb. by pointing to the enormous increase of production that followed upon its imposition. Let me remind him that the important thing is not quantity, but quality. Of the 13,000,000 lb. produced last year, not one-third was of the quality demanded by the Australian smoker: The honorable senator stressed our adverse trade balance with the United States of America, and pointed to it as a reason for developing our own tobacco industry, so that we would not have to import from America. He ignored the fact, however, that for years leaf was imported from America, on which millions of pounds of revenue was obtained. The value of those importations in relation, to the revenue obtained by the Commonwealth Government on them was low. In 1929-30, imports of tobacco leaf from the United States of America were valued at £1,739,423, which includes cigarette leaf. The revenue collected on this, both import and excise, was approximately £5,800,000, so that for every pound remitted to the United States of America for leaf, the Common wealth collected £3 7s. 6d. In addition to this benefit, considerable employment was provided by the importers.

speech.para: The honorable senator must know quite well that the reduction of the Australian crop to 6,000,000 lb. this year has nothing whatever to do with the reduction of duty. Blue mould and unfavorable seasonal conditions are alone responsible for the decline in production. As great an area is being planted to-day as ever, notwithstanding the fact that it is enjoying only 300 per cent, protection! I put it to honorable senators that the industry is sufficiently protected as it is. It is being looked . after in the only way that will ensure its becoming an economic and sound undertaking. There is hope for the industry under the existing tariff, but there would be no hope for it if we were to encourage its growth in the way that has been done in the past. It would kill itself. Senator Hardy said that we should develop the tobacco' industry. I agree, but we should not coddle it, because in that way we should encompass its destruction. In Canada, the industry has prospered with protection amounting only to1s. 8d. per lb., which it receives under the excise tariff. Senator Hardy does not disguise the fact that his proposal for varying the excise rate would, if given effect, be merely another way of giving the industry additional protection. The Assistant Treasurer (Senator Massy Greene) has addressed the Senate on the financial effects of varying the duty. I assure honorable senators that the Government has the interests of the industry at heart. We gave evidence of that during the regime of the Bruce-Page Government, and we continue to do so to-day. If honorable senators wish to bring the industry to ruin, they will insist upon a reduction of the excise duty on Australian leaf used in manufacture.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 5 agreed to.

talk.start.para: . - The Government must oppose this request. Excise duties have a vital bearing on revenue, and I have been assured that, if this request be agreed to, £1,672,000 will be lost to the revenue. The Government has noted the representations of honorable senators on this subject, and will give them full consideration at the proper time, but that time is not now.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

speech.para: I appeal to honorable senators to support this reasonable request. Although the Government appears to be very anxious to obtain revenue by means of customs and excise duties, it did not hesitate to agree to a reduction of the customs duties on ale and beer to the extent of threepence a gallon.

talk.start.para: - That was as ; a result of a special agreement.

- Under that arrangement the price of imported ale and beer has been reduced by 3d. a gallon in bulk. and 3d. a dozen in bottles. I am submitting this request, not in the interests of those engaged in the brewing trade, but on behalf of the hop and barley growers, the timber-getters, and others indirectly and vitally interested in the production of this commodity.
- Would the beer drinker derive any benefit?

- It has been definitely stated by those in the brewing trade that if a reduction were made in the excise, to the extent I propose, they would pass on the whole of the benefit to retailers, and insist on that section of the trade passing it on to the consumers.
- Would they be able to pass it on?

- They have given a definite promise to that effect. I submit that it would be an easy matter for the Government to police it. If those engaged in the trade did not honour their promise, I should be one of the first to urge the Government to revert to the existing excise duties. I make this appeal on behalf of those producers engaged in the production of commodities used in the manufacture of ale and beer, and I trust that the committee will agree to my request.

.- In view of the definite assurance given by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes), Senator Johnston, and Senator Grant, that a reduction of excise would result in a heavier consumption of ale and beer, I feel compelled to vote for the retention, of the present duties. Anything that tends to decrease the consumption of ale and beer will have my support. I shall not support any proposal that may result in increasing the consumption of alcoholic liquor.

. - I support the request moved by Senator Grant. Senator Payne should voice his criticisms of this industry to those of his constituents who are engaged in bop-growing in the Derwent Valley. Although many of them have lost their crops, they have to pay heavy rates of interest to the banking institutions from which they have obtained advances. Hopgrowing is the chief industry in the Derwent Valley, and it is only right that every assistance should be given to this and other sections of primary producers. Australians are moderate drinkers. Again I am reminded of the lines -

quote.para: The Frenchman likes his sparkling wine,
The Gorman his lager beer;
The Englishman his half-and-half,
And swears it brings good cheer;
The Scotchman likes his whisky neat,
The Irishman likes it hot;
Australians have no national drink -
They like the blasted lot.

talk.start.para: . - In reply to the question of the Minister (Senator McLachlan) as to whether a reduction of excise would be passed on to the consumer, I may say that when in Sydney last week, I was interviewed by the secretary, Mr.. Durham, and a Mr. Connolly, who, I believe, is president of the Licensed Victuallers Association of New South Wales, in connexion with this matter. These gentlemen informed me that they could give a definite assurance to the Government - I believe they have already done so in writing - that if the excise duty on ale and beer were reduced by 4d. a gallon as provided in the request moved by Senator Grant, a glass of beer for which 4d. is now charged in Sydney would be sold for 3d.
- Those engaged in the trade would have to stand some of the reduction.

- That may be so. The reduction proposed is the lowest that would enable them to reduce the cost to consumers in Sydney. [ imagine that a similar reduction would be made in Melbourne. It would have been much easier to pass on a reduction of 6d. a gallon,' but I know that a reduction of excise to the extent suggested would benefit the consumers in the direction mentioned in Melbourne and Sydney. Throughout Australia licensed victuallers have promised that the whole of any reduction of excise duty will be passed on to the public.

. I decline to vote on this item in order to appeal to primary producers, or to make my vote the medium of voicing social ideals as suggested by Senator Payne. This is purely a taxing provision, .and it should be considered entirely from that viewpoint. It appears from the figures that we have reached the point at which what economists term "the 'law of diminishing returns" is beginning to operate. . Instead of duties of this kind producing more revenue, they are producing le3s. I did not support the request moved by Senator Dunn, because it appeared to me that the probable loss of revenue mentioned by the Minister in charge of the bill was so great as to make us pause. But here we have an opportunity to test whether, in fact, the law of diminishing returns is operating. In this case, the risk is not bo great.
- Is the honorable senator aware that consumption increased by 1,000,000 gallons last year?

- I am quite aware that in this, as in other matters, there- is always more than one factor to be considered. When it is said that there has been a great falling off, a part of it - probably the greater part - may be due to the fact that the purchasing power of the people has been decreased. But, the experience in Great Britain, where the position is parallel to ours, seems to show that the falling off in the consumption of alcoholic liquor has been due to the fact that there the point mentioned by economists has been reached, and that in order to produce more revenue, it has been found necessary to reduce excise duties. I shall support this request which provides for a small reduction of the duties.

speech.para: Senator McLACHLAN(South Australia - Vice-President of the Executive the deficiency in revenue caused by a reduction of the excise, to the extent proposed, an increase in consumption of at least 25 per cent, would he necessary. I have a good deal of sympathy with those who suggest that a reduction of excise duties might result in increased consumption; but that is a matter which the Government will have to consider in connexion with its budget proposals.

talk.start.para: .- I am in entire agreement with the proposal submitted by Senator Grant, providing for a reduction of the excise duties in order to restore revenue from this source to the point it reached some time ago, because the imposition of heavy excise duties has, in many instances, resulted in decreasing rather than increasing revenue. The Assistant Treasurer (Senator Massy 'Greene) has, however, told us that these and other duties are being taken into consideration by the Government in framing the budget. I have promised the Licensed Victuallers Association in Queensland that I will do all in my power to assist them in the direction of granting relief in matters of taxation, and I think it fair to grant relief in this direction. "We have no right to endeavour to bring about prohibition by means of taxation. "We had a very fair statement from the Assistant Treasurer when we were dealing with the import duties on whisky, and we had another fair statement to-day. I believe that the Government is endeavouring, where possible, to give relief from taxation. Accordingly, I intend to support the item. . I trust that when the budget is presented the Government will give relief to the brewing industry, which has been hit very hard in recent years.

speech.para: Senator Sir WALTERKINGSMILL(Western Australia) [2.47]. - I intend to support the request, because I think that it is essentially fair. Furthermore, from my knowledge of the inhabitants of Sydney, I believe that the undertaking given to Senator Johnston will be honoured. I admit, of course, that it is unenforceable, but, at all events, it will be a test of the moral sense of those whom the reduction is supposed to benefit. Believing that a reduction of the excise duty will enable the price of the commodity to be reduced from 4d. to , 3d. a glass with out endangering the revenue in any way, I intend to vote for the request.

talk.start.para: [2.49]. - Again I appeal to the committee to consider the budget aspect of these excise duties. To me, it seems to be utterly wrong to deal with individual items in the schedule, and decide that the excise on this one shall be so much, and the excise on others some other amount. The Treasurer is required to produce what I regard as a balanced budget - something that will appeal to the country, and assist to keep industry going. To do this, regard must be paid to all the factors that affect industry and the revenue. If the committee of the Senate decides that the excise on beer shall be an amount less than that provided, and that the excise on tobacco shall also be less than is set out in the schedule, is it not apparent to honorable senators that much of the preparatory work in connexion with the budget will be destroyed ? If the Treasurer, when considering his budget arrangements, knows that the Senate committee has reached a certain decision in regard to the excise on some of these items, will not his position be rendered almost impossible?
- May no alteration of the excise duties be made by the Senate?

- I do not suggest that the Senate should not exercise its full right, subject to its constitutional limitations, but we must recognize that responsibility for the financial policy of the Commonwealth belongs to another place. I think honorable senators generally will admit that.
- No.

- That, at all events, has always been my understanding of the constitutional position of the two branches of the legislature. The mere fact that the Senate cannot alter a money bill is evidence of the limitation of its constitutional power. All it can do is to make requests for amendments.
- Which is the same thing.

- That, in itself, is definite evidence of responsibility in regard to the budget residing in the House of Representatives. I, therefore, appeal, to the committee not to hamper the Treasurer in the preparation of the budget, by carrying requests for a reduction of the excise on this or any other item, which necessarily will mean reduced revenue. I appeal to honorable senators, as far as possible, and in accordance with their conscience, to leave the Government free to arrange the budget in such a way as to be able to do the best possible thing for the country. As I stated this morning, the requested amendments forecast would, if agreed to, mean a reduction of the revenue by approximately £2,600,000, thus making it impossible for the Government to give full effect to its proposals for relief from taxation in other directions. It is desirable that, as far as possible, the Government should be free to frame its budget without any impediment, such as would be interposed if the request were carried.

speech.para: SenatorRAE (New South Wales) [2.53]. - If the remarks of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Massy Greene) mean anything, they mean that, if the committee does not wish to embarrass the Government, it must refrain from making any alterations to this schedule of excise duties, because every argument that has been adduced in support of the requested amendment to reduce the excise duty on beer applies with equal force to many other items. Consequently, if we accept the argument of the Assistant Treasurer, the discussion of the schedule is a mere farce. If the constitutional position of the Senate is so weak that it is forbidden to request any alteration of the excise duties, then the Government should run the country without the aid of Parliament.

Senator SirWALTER KINGSMILL (Western Australia) [2.55]. - I have every sympathy with Treasurers, because I know that their task is a -very difficult one ; but if the reasoning of the Assistant Treasurer is carried to -its logical conclusion, the committee of the Senate must not interfere in any way with customs and excise duties, or, indeed, with the Estimates, for fear of embarrassing the Government. I refuse to subscribe to that view.

talk.start.para: - I do not think that the Assistant Treasurer's remarks are capable of that construction.
- I cannot see how they can be construed otherwise.
- They were not intended to be taken in that way.

- I am glad to have that assurance from the Leader of the Senate; but I repeat that, if the observations of the Assistant Treasurer are carried to their logical conclusion, and if any alteration of this schedule would cause confusion, the position would become intolerable to both the Senate and the Treasurer. The constitutional limits indicated by the Assistant Treasurer are not imposed, or sought to be imposed, on the second chamber of any Parliament in Australia. I definitely refuse to subscribe to that view of the position of the Senate.

. - All that the Senate can do is to make a request to another place to alter the duties. Therefore, the carrying of this request would be merely a gesture to another place. How, then, could it cause confusion, or be embarrassing to the Government, or be regarded by the Treasurer as an impediment in the preparation of the budget? I cannot follow the reasoning of the Assistant Treasurer, and I intend to support the request.

talk.start.para: . - I move -
