speech.para: This request is made because of the statement of the Minister (Senator McLachlan) in this chamber a few weeks ago, in regard to consideration being given to the reduction of the duty on Scotch whisky. It is felt that the present is an appropriate occasion to impress on the Government the fact that Australian whisky should be treated on at least as generous a basis as that on which it is proposed to deal with Scotch whisky. For the five years ended the 30th June, 1930, the average annual quantity of Australian whisky upon which excise duty was paid was 211,588 gallons. During the succeeding two years the quantities on which excise duty was paid were : 1931, 151,357 gallons; 1932, 141,429 gallons. It will be seen that the consumption for 1932 was 70,159 gallons below the annual average for the five-year period to the 30th June, 1930. The figures for the year ended the 30th June, 1933, are not yet available. They will, however, show a further drop. The position that has arisen is one of grave concern to all the distillery interests' in the Commonwealth. Some years ago there were five distilleries in Victoria making whisky, one in New South Wales, and one in South Australia. The distillery in New South Wales was closed many years ago, but three of the distilleries in Victoria have been operating full time until the last two years.

The serious decrease in the consumption of Australian whisky, which has arisen from causes entirely outside the control of the distilleries, and is mainly ascribable to the high taxation on the commodity, has caused a condition of grave concern to 'the shareholders in these Australian companies, and has resulted in a considerable diminution of employment. There has been an entire cessation of whisky-distilling in Victoria, in which the industry was mainly centred. The only distilleries now operating are two small distilleries in South Australia, both of which are of comparatively recent establishment, and neither of which is a major factor in the trade. It is estimated that there is enough Australian whisky now in bonded warehouses in the Commonwealth to last for twenty years, with consumption at the present rate. If the Government wishes to improve the consumption in the interests of revenue, it is obvious that the only way to secure the release of these huge stocks of whisky that are unsaleable at the present time owing to the high prices that have to be charged to secure the excise duty of 28s. a proof gallon imposed by the Commonwealth G-overnment, is to lower the duty to such a figure as will enable the public again to consume this commodity. The figures I have given show that it is not the quality of the spirit produced, but the all-important factor of price, that has been responsible for the drop in trade. The Victorian distilleries at present wholly closed down are the Federal, Port Melbourne; Dunnstown, Ballarat; and Corio, Geelong. Two of these distilleries are equipped with the most up-to-date plant, and in the past they have given a great deal of employment. Moreover, from the point of view of the primary producer, they have been large users of grain, most of which has been produced in Victoria and South Australia. The average amount of barley and malt used in any one of these distilleries exceeds 100,000 bushels per annum, which meant a profitable outlet for the grower. In addition to the loss to the grain producer, there has also been a loss in wages, fuel, water, and other charges incidental to the process of manufacture. It is estimated that, in the Victorian distilleries alone, there was distributed in the various avenues mentioned something like £1,500 a week. The entire cessation of distilling, involving the economic loss of this expenditure, is solely due to the fact that the industry has been taxed out of existence. I believe that, if the excise duty were reduced, the . Government would receive a greater amount of revenue as' the result of increased consumption as was experienced in Great Britain.

talk.start.para: . - It is quite true, as the honorable senator has stated, that withdrawals of whisky from bond decreased steadily from 1927-28 to 1931-32, when they appeared to become static. The figures for last year are not yet complete, but I understand that they will probably show a slight decrease. When dealing with the customs duty on whisky for blending purposes, I indicated to the honorable senator, and to other honorable senators who were associated with him in his request for the reduction of the duty, that the matter has to be considered as a whole. Should any relief be given by way of customs duty, the excise duty will have to be brought into harmony with the position thus created. The action that I took in regard to blended whisky shows that there is a disposition on the part of the Government to assist the industry to increase its output. I shall presently propose a similar request in connexion with the excise duty. I assure the honorable senator that the matter is having the closest consideration of the Government, and I ask him not to press his request.

speech.para: Question - That the request (Senator E. B. Johnstons) be agreed to - put. the committee divided. (Chairman -Senator the Hon. Herbert Hays.)

subdebate.1.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend sub-item, (D) by leaving out - "And on and after 1st October, 1935 -

item.label: (D)
item.para: Whisky, distilled wholly from barley malt by a pot-still or similar process at a strength not exceeding 45 per cent, over proof, matured by storage in wood for a period of not less than three years, and certified by an officer to be pure malt whisky, per proof gallon, 28s."

speech.para: My first reason for doing so is that, in 1931, the House of Representatives altered the period required for maturation of Australian whisky from two to three years, so creating a differentiation between brandy and whisky for which, on the merits of the case, there is no justification. My second reason is that the matter does not adversely affect the revenue; actually the shorter period of maturation would put forward the collection of the excise by twelve months.

One might reasonably ask why different periods of maturation should be prescribed for brandy and whisky. A reference to Hansard discloses that, on the 16th October, 1931, the House of Representatives altered the period for whisky from two to three years, and since then the matter has not been referred to this committee for consideration in detail - although, I suppose, it has been covered in general terms by a validating act. The amendment was submitted by the member for Wide Bay (Mr. Bernard Corser) and supported by Messrs. Nairn, Bayley, R. Green, McGrath and Riley. The then Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Forde) opposed the proposal, and stated that he had received notice of it only a day or two before, and asked for permission to refer the matter to the Tariff Board for investigation and report. The honorable gentleman also pointed out that while the proposal apparently had the approval of the United Distilleries, it would prove a hardship to the smaller distilleries, particularly in South Australia, a forecast which has since proved correct. Despite- the protests of the Minister for Trade and Customs, the amendment wa3 carried on the voices, with, I submit, inadequate discussion, and mainly on the argument that maturation for three years would make Australian whisky a more palatable, healthy drink. One honorable member said that no whisky drinker would consume whisky if he knew that it had been matured for only two years, an absurd argument which I hope to refute in the few minutes that I shall need to detain the committee in connexion with this matter.

talk.start.para: - Some persons would not care if it had been matured for .only five minutes.
- Of course they would not. Does any honorable senator, when going into the bar at a railway station, pause to ask the purveyor of whisky the age of the particular brand that he is providing?
- I undertake that the honorable senator always specifies a brand which he knows has been matured for over two years.

- I am not speaking against adequate maturation, but wish to prove, scientifically, that it is impossible to distinguish between two Australian whiskies which have been matured, respectively, for two and three years. The argument against a 3-year period of maturation is, however, not concerned with that aspect, the main consideration being that the longer period has had a detrimental effect on the smaller distilleries. Obviously, the longer period of maturation is of advantage to old established distilleries because of the greater amount of capital that it will keep "frozen", thus discouraging new firms from beginning business. 1, personally, d'o not stand for preventing persons from putting their capital into industry merely to conserve the interests of one large concern, which has had a great start, but believe that the new firm should also be given a chance.

speech.para: The arguments on which I rely are first that a 2-year period of maturation was adopted in Australia in 1906 on the recommendation of the Royal- Commission on Customs and Excise Tariffs, and remained unaltered until 1931, being then altered after a discussion of about a quarter of an hour and without any sound reason having been advanced for the change. My second reason is that a term of two years is at present, in force in Canada. It is true that the period in England is three years, but I shall show from quotations that whisky matures much more rapidly in Australia than it does in the Mother Country, and that whisky that has been kept in wood in Australia for two years is equal to that which has been kept in wood for four years in England. Dr. Hargreaves, the Government Analyst and Director of the Department of Chemistry in South Australia, was given a number of bottles of whisky ranging over a period of five years, which he tested, and he found that it was not possible to detect the effect of the maturity on the spirit from year to year. In his report, Dr. Hargreaves cited not only his own experiments, but also a number of authorities, including Crampton and Tolman, the Bureau of Inland Revenue of the United States of America, and Alcohol and ils Production, by C. Simmonds. The testimony of this leading chemist, the gist of which I now quote, should finally dispose of the contention that public health is being conserved by increasing the period of maturation from two years to three years -

quote.para: In Australia, usually, the water goes out (through the wood) at a faster rate than the alcohol, owing to high evaporation. ... In Great Britain, water evaporates at a slower rate proportionately than does the alcohol, and there is a loss of alcoholic strength on keeping . . . Throughout all the published figures relating to American and Scotch spirits which I have seen, the outstanding evidence is that the major portion of the changes during storage occurs during the first few months, and certainly within the first year, and a general view shows that there is little advantage in storing for two years over one year, and less advantage still for storage for three years over two years. . . .

speech.para: I may mention that the change in alcohol, when stored in bottles, is negligible over a period of years -

quote.para: There is a well-defined difference between the new spirit and the one year old sample, but there are no marked differences between the one year old, the two years old, the three years old and the four years old spirits.

It may be. said that the undesirable constituents in whisky that can be removed or changed by storage, are so removed or changed during the first few months, and any subsequent storage is for the purpose of improving colour, . flavour and aroma, and increasing the extra or " body ". These things depend, as already pointed out, much more upon the kind of cask than upon the timein which the spirit is stored therein.

speech.para: Obviously, there is no foundation for the contention that the virtues of Australian whisky are improved1 by storage for three years instead of two years. Dr. Hargreaves continues -

quote.para: With our greater evaporation, we should obtain sufficient maturity and concentration in half the time required in Great Britain, so that storage for two' years in South Australia should produce as wholesome spirit as would be obtained in England or Scotland in four years. . . .

Speaking generally, there is no evidence, either from these samples or from the analytical data that I have seen with respect to other spirits, to show that spirits matured in wood for two years are not so good and wholesome as those stored for three years. . . . There is, however, much evidence to indicate that spirits should be kept for some months, say, up to twelve months. Beyond that the improvement is more a matter of the kind of cask than of the number of years of storage.

speech.para: That is the case against the alteration, made hurriedly and without adequate consideration, of the standard that had been in operation for 25 years.

. - In regard to the scientific side of the matter, Senator DuncanHughes has made out a strong case; hut, legally, we seem to have placed ourselves in a cleft stick. I regard a duty of 30s. a gallon on rum as another injustice to a Queensland industry, because most of the rum manufactured in Australia is produced in that State. Prior to the Ottawa Conference, rum made in Australia enjoyed a protective margin of11s. a gallon over imported rum. Now that margin is only 6s. a gallon. The protective margin is 18s. a gallon in the case of brandy, and 17s. a gallon on both whisky and gin. Why should it be only 6s. a gallon on rum? We are told that rum is a spirit of lower quality than whisky or brandy, and that its use should not be encouraged. talk.start.para: . - The proposed excise duties on both standard and blended ruin represent an increase of 2s. a gallon on the 1921-28 excise tariff. The proposed rates are the same as those imposed by the Scullin Government. There has been a marked decline in the demand for rum, with the result that the distilleries, which are confined mainly to Queensland, have been unable to dispose of their output. The rum-producing interests have engaged in extensive propaganda against both the customs and the excise duties. The first contention was that the Government's action in extending the British preferential rate to rum which is the product of British colonies had adversely affected Australian production. An examination of import statistics covering the period subsequent to the Ottawa agreement showed that the imports were practically negligible, and definitely established that this contention was entirely fallacious. The rum-producers then argued that the disparity between the excise duties on whisky and rum - the excise duty on rum is 2s. a gallon higher than on whisky - was responsible for the decline in the demand for rum; but an analysis of the figures covering the customs and excise clearances of spirits from bond in recent years, which form a reliable guide to the quantities of the respective spirits going into consumption, does not support this contention. Taking the customs and excise clearances for 1928-29 as a basis of comparison, we find that the consumption of whisky has declined 57.2 per cent., whereas the drop in the consumption of rum is only 48.3 per cent. During the last fiscal year 283,000 gallons of Australian rum were cleared from bond, compared with only 142,000 gallons of Australian whisky. It is also interesting to note that 71 per cent, of the whisky consumed was imported whisky, which carried customs duties ranging from 45s. to 53s. per gallon. On the other hand, almost the whole of the rum which went into consumption was of Australian origin, dutiable at 30s. a gallon. Imported rum comprised less than 9,000 gallons out of a total consumption of 292,000 gallons. Furthermore, the reduction of 2s. a proof gallon, when applied to sales in the nobbier, is so small that it could not be passed on to consumers. It is, therefore, difficult to see how the desired reduction would increase the demand for rum.

speech.para: When it is remembered that rum is produced from molasses, a by-product in the manufacture of sugar, and that whisky is produced from primary products, such as barley and other grains, which it is impossible to produce at anything approaching the price at which molasses is obtainable, it will be evident to honorable senators that the rumproducers are in a most advantageous position in the matter of costs, and are, therefore, in a position to carry the higher impost.

talk.start.para: . - It has been argued that the small margin of protection given to rum as compared with that given to other spirits is justified because of the cheapness of the raw materials used in its production, but I would point out to honorable senators that similar circumstances exist in other countries which produce rum. The Minister has failed to make out a good case for retaining this small margin of protection.

- My comparison was between rum and whisky produced locally, and not between local rum and the product of other countries. The manufacture of whisky is a complete process, whereas rum is merely a byproduct.

- A similar position exists in Jamaica. The local manufacturers of rum should receive something approximating the protection given to the local manufacturers of whisky. Mention has been made of the propaganda circulated by the Queensland distillers of rum, but I have not seen or heard of it. I admit that I have received letters from Thomas Brown and Sons, and from a Bundaberg distillery, but no complaint can be made about that, because it is only natural that they would bring under the notice of their Queensland representatives in this chamber the disabilities under which they are suffering because of the small margin of preference given to them under the customs and excise legislation of the Commonwealth.

. - The excise on Australian brandies and whiskies is 2s. less than it is on Queensland rum, and if the request of Senator Brown is agreed to the excise on those three commodities will be brought into line. Previously, Australian rum enjoyed a marginal difference of lis. a proof gallon over foreign rum, the respective rates being 30s. and 41s.- a gallon. The recent decisions at Ottawa reduced the import duty on foreign rum, including that from the West Indies, to 36s., and in the short time that has elapsed since then there has been a considerable increase in the importation of rum notwithstanding that it is the product of black labour.
- The official figures show that there has been no increase of importations.

- At any rate, the Ottawa agreement has left the door open for the importation into Australia of rum from the West Indies produced by black-sweated labour. Australian brandy enjoys a marginal difference of 18s. a gallon over imported brandy, and gin and whisky have an advantage of 17s. a gallon. In the case of rum, however, the marginal difference is only 6s. a gallon. Those rates give an unfair preference to the other spirits, and place rum at a disadvantage. Queensland is the only place in the world in. which rum is produced by white labour. Not only the rum itself, but also every ingredient used in its manufacture in Australia is produced by white labour. I hope that the committee will agree to the request of Senator Brown.

. - I wish to explain my attitude on this item, which may seem to some honorable senators to be inconsistent. speech.para: The object of my request is to provide for a differentiation of1s. 6d. per lb. between the excise rate on tobacco made from imported leaf and that on tobacco made from Australian-grown leaf. The Minister in charge of the bill denied that there was any moral obligation on the present Government to the Australian tobacco-growers because of what was done by the Scullin Government.. Let me draw a parallel to show that the Minister was wrong. Suppose one Government encouraged migration on a large scale, and a succeeding government, opposed to migration, sought to wash its hands of all responsibility with regard to those migrants who had been encouraged to come to Australia. Would the Minister say that the succeeding government had no moral obligation in the matter? The more we study the history of tobacco-growing in Australia, and the sudden expansion of the industry in recent years, the more convinced we become that a great deal of the development - I do not say all of it - was due to the Scullin tariff. The Minister smiles, and he reminds me of the "smile on the face of the tiger". No doubt, he will claim that the Scullin duties were in operation only for a limited number of months; but even that was sufficient to cause a tremendous number of primary producers and others to take up tobacco-growing. It is easy to perceive what has happened by noting the development of the industry, even in my own district. It has been said that an excise duty of 3s. a lb. affords ample protection to the growers. The Minister has declared, without hesitation, "It is 300 per cent, protection ". How did he arrive at that figure? The average price paid to the growers last year was from 2s. to 2s. 3d. per lb., and the import duty . to-day amounts to 3s. per lb. The Minister has said repeatedly . - and the statement is also made in the Tariff Board's report - that the protection afforded to this industry amounts to 300 per cent.; but how can that be so when the average price realized last year for 8,000,000 lb. of the Australian crop was about 2s. 3d. per lb. Taking the difference between that price and the import duty of 3s. per lb., the protection amounts to only 50 per cent.

I realize that the Government will win or lose, on this issue, on the ground that the revenue- would suffer if the excise were lowered. I anticipate that certain honorable senators who represent primary producing States are not prepared to support my request. They say, " We must not interfere with the revenue required by the Government ". The revenue received from tobacco in 1932-33 amounted to £7,300,000 ; but the Government did not budget for that amount. It planned to receive from that source only £6,100,000. What right ha3 the Government to extract from those who use tobacco an additional £1,212,988? In view of the estimate of £6,100,000, it cannot be contended that a reduction of the excise on Australian leaf to 3s. per lb., thus reducing the revenue for 1933-34 to £6,600,000 odd, would greatly embarrass the Government. The position of the tobacco-growers of Australia is serious, because 4,000 or more of them are faced with ruin. The Government claims that their deplorable position is due to an act of Goi ; but we have, to consider the price they will get for their diminished crop, and the bigger that price is the better chance they will' have of recovering from the set-back they have received through bad seasonal conditions. Taking the industry as a whole, I think that it may be said that the season just past was the worst that has been experienced by the growers. I submit my request for the reason that the year's revenue will not be affected by it for more than three months, and also on cbe ground of justice, because the high duties previously imposed encouraged the growers to invest their small savings in growing tobacco leaf. The Government might well give them a fighting chance of success until the industry gets safely upon its feet.

talk.start.para: .- Since February, 1932, no fewer than 23 schemes have been submitted to the Government for the revision of these duties on tobacco, and each would have involved the sacrifice of very substantial amounts of revenue. Senator Hardy's proposal is for a differentiation in the excise. The specious plea has been advanced that the purpose is to cheapen tobacco to the Australian smoker, but it is in reality nothing more than an en deavour to obtain greater protection for an industry which is already highly protected. It is true that, for the last year, the total revenue derived from narcotics increased substantially, and is about £800,000 above the amount of £6,500,000 which the Tariff Board suggested should be obtained from tobacco during the period in which the Australian leafgrowing, industry was becoming established. However, an analysis of the position shows that this additional revenue has not been obtained at the expense of the leaf -growing industry. The additional revenue has been obtained as follows: -

speech.para: Thus, out of the increase of £830,000 which has come about in the revenue, only £232,000, or 28 per cent., is borne by the Australian smoker of locally-grown leaf. This, fact is very important, and puts a vastly different complexion on the board's statement with regard to the limitation of revenues on narcotics, so that the Government cannot take the basic figure of £6,500,,000 as being a fair comparison.

It must also be borne in mind that the increased revenue returns will not be maintained when increased quantities of Australian leaf go into consumption. The duties encouraged manufacturers to place the Australian leaf into maturation instead of immediate consumption, and this i3 all to the good. If the rates had not encouraged maturation, it is certain greater quantities of Australian leaf would have been marketed last year, and revenue returns would not have been nearly so great. Although an immediate increase in revenue is being experienced, the ultimate result will be a loss of revenue, as the crop of 11,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf which was produced, purchased, and placed into maturation last year,, is gradually released and placed on the market. ' For every pound so used, 3s. impart duty will be lost.

On next year's budgeted usings, Senator Hardy's proposal for a reduction of1s. 6d. per lb. on tobacco manufactured from Australian leaf would involve a loss of £323,000. As the very . object of his request is to ensure a greater use of Australian- leaf, it is apparent that the loss would be much greater than this. If a swing-over to 1,000,000 lb. of Australian stemmed leaf, additional to that budgeted for, occurred, the loss would be £560,674. If a swing-over to 2,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf occurred, the loss would be £798,424; if 3,000,000 lb., it would be £1,036,174. These figures indicate how our carefully planned finances could be so easily wrecked.

Honorable senators might consider these calculations somewhat academic, but that they are very real and practical. Quite early after, the changed duties were brought down in February, 1932, growers' representatives, and others interested, said that the department was in error in estimating that year's Australian crop at from 10,000,000 lb. to 11,000,000 lb. The growers' estimate was 6,000,000 lb. The actual crop was 13,000,000 lb. And so with these revenue figures the department advised the previous Government that its proposed amendments would defeat themselves. At that time, revenue from tobacco was £6,500,000 per annum. The previous Government decided that it wanted another £1,000,000 from tobacco. It never got it. Instead, it received £6,300,000. Diminished consumption was not the sole reason. The point which was overlooked by the last Government was that the time had arrived when increased excise duties had to be imposed in order to maintain the revenue, let alone the securing of an additional £1,000.000.

The present duties on tobacco are fixed at such a level as will permit the industry to develop along sound, economic lines, and, at the same time, ensure that the revenue will be maintained. The granting of further protection, either by an increased duty on imported leaf, or by a reduction of excise on Australian leaf, would mean that the production of darker grades of leaf, for which there is only a limited demand, would be reverted to, and the industry would relapse into that chaotic condition from which it was rescued last year. Any sincere claim for additional protection of Australian-grown leaf must start from the point that Australian growers are not obtaining satisfactory prices. No evidence has been submitted to prove this. Last year's prices were exceedingly satisfactory, and all the crop was sold. This year's results of auction sales were also very satisfactory, as the following figures show:-

It is evident that every pound of good quality tobacco leaf produced in Australia finds a ready and profitable market. If some growers persist in growing dark leaf, and do not sell it, the manufacturers cannot be blamed, nor can the Government be held responsible. In the final analysis, the smoker is the person who insists upon the production of quality tobacco. His taste must be respected, and no organization of growers, nor the Government, can balk this fact.

Finally, no Government can afford to lose hundreds of thousands of pounds in revenue to assist growers who do not produce the class of tobacco demanded by Australian smokers. If this request is agreed to, revenue will undoubtedly be lost. Tobacco is regarded as one of those commodities which may legitimately be taxed by governments for revenue purposes, and if the honorable senator's proposal is accepted, other primary producers, who are more deserving, may have to suffer. The increase in the production of tobacco in Australia has, in many instances, been responsible for unduly inflating land values. Tobacco-growing is the most profitable primary industry in Australia.

talk.start.para: - The Minister is quite wrong.

- Those who have not invested money in, or have been closely associated with the industry, are not conversant with all the details. I know that the returns from properlymatured tobacco leaf are better than those from any other Australian primary product.
- The Minister should produce the figures.

- I have the figures for last year in my possession. Growers, of course, have to contend with climatic conditions and pests, but the returns of many growers have been highly satisfactory. If the excise duties are reduced, the result in Australia may be as it was in the United States of America. In the early stages of tobacco growing the producers in that country were asked to contribute a fair share to the revenue, but there was such a clamour that they escaped paying their fair quota, and, even to-day, the revenue derived from tobacco in the United States of America, as compared with that received from other sources, is lower than it should be. I shall oppose the request in the interests of the tobacco-growing industry, because I believe that in doing so I shall be assisting to place it on an economic basis.

. - I would not have spoken but for the extravagant and inaccurate statements of the Minister (Senator McLachlan). When replying to the debate on the second reading of the bill he said that the Australian tobacco growers enjoy a protection of 300 per cent. They enjoy no such protection. What are the actual facts? The manufacturer of imported tobacco has to pay about ls. per lb. to land the leaf in Australia, and a customs duty of 3s. per lb., making a total cost of 4s. per lb. to cover the cost of the raw material and customs duty. To that is added a flat rate of excise of 4s. 6d. per lb., making the total cost of the raw material and customs and excise duties 83. 6d. per lb. On the other hand, what has the Australian manufacturer to pay for the right to manufacture and market Australian tobacco? The average price of Australian tobacco last year was 2s. 3d. per lb., but to that we have to add an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb., making a total of 6s. 9d. per lb. for raw material and excise duty. The difference between 8s. 6d. per lb. and 6s. 9d. per lb is not 300 per cent., as the Minister stated, but only 33 per cent.
- That is a novel way of arriving at the true position.

- It is the only basis upon which it can be argued. Before, one ounce of imported or Australian tobacco can be sold the manufacturer has to buy the leaf and pay the customs and excise duties imposed by this Parliament. The only protection that the Australian tobacco-grower enjoys is approximately 33 per cent. But granted that the Minister's figures are correct, what have he and the officers of the Customs Department been doing to permit manufacturers to charge the prices they do? I have found it difficult to obtain Australian tobacco, but I have tried three different kinds and found that it compares favorably with the imported leaf. The actual difference in the retail price of imported and Australian tobacco is id. per oz. Where does the 300 per cent, come in? I believe that the quality of Australian tobacco is equal, if not superior, to the imported. I have been informed by experts that the peculiar properties of certain tobacco which make it more palatable to some smokers are due to the soil in which it is grown, and also to the climate in which it is produced. Twelve months ago when Dr. Dickson, the Commonwealth tobacco expert, delivered a most interesting lecture on tobacco in the Senate club room, he said that even if we imported the best tobacco plants from overseas and adopted overseas cultural methods, we could not produce tobacco with the same aroma as the imported leaf owing to the difference in soil and climate. Australian smokers have become accustomed to the taste and aroma of the imported tobacco, and the only way to encourage them to smoke Australian-grown leaf is by reducing the price of the Australian product. The proposals of this Government, unlike those of the previous Government, will not assist in that direction. I support the request moved by Senator Hardy.

.- The Minister (Senator McLachlan) stated, a few minutes ago, that between the time of the alteration of the duty and the present day, 23 different schemes for the assistance of the industry had been submitted to the Government for consideration. Senator SAMPSON(Tasmania) £4.33]. - During the last twelve months, we have been inundated with literature explaining the pros and cons of the tobacco industry. Those of us who represent States in which tobacco is no't grown to any extent - in Tasmania it ha3 been grown for many years, but not in any quantity - may be regarded as outsiders or spectators who, it is generally believed, " see most of the game." The study of Tariff Board reports and the different statements put out by tobacco-growing associations and other bodies, is rather informative. 'Some interesting statements have been made during the course of this debate. "On the one hand it has been said that the tobacco-grower is threatened with industrial extinction, and that he is &t present scratching along almost on the breadline. On the other hand, it has been said that he has been on a very good wicket in a most profitable occupation. It it most difficult to reconcile those statements. I' believe that there is not the slightest doubt that last year and the year before, a largs number of persons were tempted by the profitable returns to grow tobacco. Then, the problem of marketing arose. I think it can be said that it was the definite policy of the Australian manufacturers last year - and that it still is - to use Australian leaf to the greatest possible extent. That is proved by the appreciable variation that has occurred in the quality of well-known brands of tobacco, due to the fact that a fairly large proportion of not quite suitable leaf has been mixed with the imported leaf. Consistent smokers must have noticed that variation. I have been a smoker for 30 odd years, and during the last twelve months, I have had to chop and change among the different brands. Some Australian tobacco is excellent, some is fair, and some is perfectly horrible. That, of course, applies also to tobacco grown in other countries. For six or seven years, I lived in Rhodesia, where I attempted to grow tobacco. The problem in that country has been the marketing of what is not first-grade leaf. The Australian manufacturer has used a large proportion of Australian leaf; but there are limits to 'its use.', The ultimate success of both the growing and the . manufacturing, branches of the industry in Australia rests- with the smoker, about whom we have not heard much during this debate. The quality of the tobacco marketed must be so high that it will be palatable to him. The Government could, of course, follow the lead given by France and other countries, and permit only certain tobacco to be smoked; but God forbid that wi should ever be placed in that position! The less said about the quality of the government monopoly tobacco in France, the better. The Australian industry is more or less in "the experimental stage. Tobaccogrowing must be undertaken in areas that are suitable in regard to both soil and climatic conditions. I have carefully read the case put up to the Government, the reports of the Tariff Board, Dr. Dickson's statements, and anything else dealing with tobacco that I have been able to lay my hands on during the last twelve months. If one believed the statements of those who are opposed to the Government in this matter, one could only come to the conclusion that it is stark, staring mad; that it has no intelligence, brains or sense. Can it be said that the Tariff Board is absolutely ' mad, and that it has acted stupidly? The principal thing to be avoided in this industry is overproduction,' particularly of leaf that is not suitable for smoking purposes. A tremendous percentage of the crop comes under that head. If we had a big glut' of poor quality leaf, we should be in the same position as Rhodesia occupied in 1928, when it could hardy give away 19,000,000 lb. of leaf on account of the poorness of its quality. Even if we over-produced leaf of excellent quality we should have the utmost difficulty in disposing of it. We certainly have an over-production of sugar, but its quality is, probably, better than that of any other sugar. If we continued to do as we did last year in the tobacco industry, we should be landed with an overproduction of leaf of varying qualities, of which we could not possibly dispose, and the last stage of the Australian tobacco industry would be much worse than the first. I have endeavoured, after full consideration of the facts, to arrive at a fair and proper appreciation of the matter, my conclusion being that; I must support the action/of the. Government.

subdebate.1.para: I propose also to move a similar request to sub-item b, which relates to manufactured tobacco. The purpose of these requests is to establish a margin between the duties chargeable on Australian leaf and imported leaf respectively. This proposal is identical with one submitted in the* House of Representatives by the Acting Leader of the Country party (Mr. Paterson). The fact that it was rejected in that chamber by only two votes shows that it had the approval of a large proportion of those who have taken a deep interest in the Australian tobacco-growing industry. The purpose is primarily to assist the growers of tobacco by providing an incentive to smokers to use Australian-grown leaf. It is a question of deciding how a cheaper smoke can be provided for the man who has been hit hy the depression, without causing a loss of revenue to the Government. We believe that th a t -can be done. The secretary of the Victorian Tobacco Growers Association has submitted a proposal which would permit Australian tobacco to be sold for Id. less per 2-oz. packet than the present price, and for blended tobacco to be sold at rates ranging from those now charged to slightly lower prices. That would increase the difference in price that now exists between Australian and imported tobacco <o at least 1½d. for a 2-oz. packet, and would give a considerable incentive to smokers 'Jo acquire a taste for Australian tobacco. It would also lessen the difficulties associated with the disposal of Australian leaf. I shall not traverse the ground already well covered by Senators Hardy, 0'Halloran. and others; but I submit that the resultant loss of revenue from the adoption of Senator Hardy's proposal would be much less than the estimate of the Minister. My .proposal is for a very much smaller alteration than that desired by Senator Hardy. The maximum drop in the revenue which the adoption of Senator Hardy's proposal would cause would be about £300,000, not allowing for the increased consumption of tobacco which would ensue from the cheapening of this commodity. In times of depression, men are forced to place a limit on their use of luxuries. That the cheapening of a commodity in general use always increases the consumption of that commodity has been proved many times in the case of bread; as the price has fallen, so has the consumption increased. We have, therefore, to deduct from the possible losses the additional revenue which would be derived from the greater quantity of tobacco consumed. Senator Brennan, in a rather cold-blooded manner, sard that persons who invested their cash on the strength of action taken by a government through the customs house, accepted the attendant risk with their eyes open, because they 'knew that a future government could alter the duties. I dissent altogether from that view. While it must be admitted that governmental aid is a purely artificial way of stimulating industry, there can be no justification whatever for giving a sudden impetus to a new enterprise, and then bringing down the axe on it just as suddenly. Any such action must necessarily dislocate industry and destroy confidence in governments. As a general rule, one government feels bound by any undertaking entered into by its predecessor, even when that undertaking is not backed by statute law. I know that there are exceptions to that rule, but 'Other than in special circumstances it is followed. Ordinarily, we have no more right to induce people to embark on an enterprise, and then suddenly to withdraw the support given to them, than we have to borrow money under false pretences. I contend that, whatever difficulties there may be in the way of producting a high-class tobacco leaf, because of attemps to grow it in unsuitable soil, or in districts not climatically suited to its culture, the fact remains that a large proportion of the land now under tobacco is well suited to the production of high-class leaf. This industry is, therefore, not one which can be dismissed, with a shrug of the shoulders, as being of no account. On the contrary, it is an industry in which a considerable amount of capital has been invested, and the adoption of any policy which might plunge the greater number of those engaged in tobacco production into financial difficulties would be a scandalous thing to "do. A good case has been made out on behalf of the tobacco growers, who were induced by previous administrations to engage in this form of production. Moreover, in these times of depression, smokers are entitled to a better deal than they are now getting. They should be offered some inducement to acquire a taste for Australian tobacco. It is useless to argue that, if Australian tobacco were of first-class quality, smokers would be glad to smoke it without any special inducement. Quality is largely a matter of individual taste. A person who, over a period of years,

Las acquired a taste for a certain commodity, is not easily persuaded that another commodity is equally good. The way in which we can best help the tobacco-grower is to increase the demand for his product; and, if he is given a margin of protection over the foreign grower such as I propose, it will enable the locally-grown tobacco to be Bold at a price slightly lower than that of the imported tobacco, and therefore stimulate its consumption. A logical case has been made out on behalf of the Australian growers. This impost . should be permanent, but as the demand for the Australian tobacco increases, and that of the imported correspondingly diminishes, there should bo a readjustment between the customs and excise duties so as to suit the changing circumstances. I trust that the committee will agree to my request

speech.para: I desire to express the appreciation of the Government on the manner in which honorable senators have co-operated in bringing the business of the Senate to a conclusion this week. I also wish to congratulate the Senate on the close consideration which has been given to the tariff schedule. I have been in this Parliament now for 30 years. I saw the first tariff schedule put through, and all subsequent schedules, but never before has such close attention been given to any schedule in the Senate as has been given to this. Both sides of the Senate will agree with me, I am sure, in expressing our appreciation of the way in which the presiding officers, and the Chairman of Committees, have performed their duties, as also have the members of the Hansard staff and other officials during the strain of the session. They have all concentrated on doing their duty, and I express my thanks to them. Last, but not least, our thanks are due to my worthy colleague, Senator McLachlan. There are reasons, with which honorable senators are no doubt familiar, that would have made it invidious for me to have taken a prominent part in putting this tariff through the Senate. Senator McLachlan has done his job well, with little assistance from his fellow Ministers, because Cabinet has been sitting much of the time.

talk.start.para: . - In the absence of my leader (Senator Barnes), I desire to join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Pearce) in expressing appreciation of the splendid work which has been done by the responsible officers of this chamber during the passage of the tariff schedule. The Chairman of Committees and the officers of the Senate have performed their duties in a most praiseworthy manner. The Minister (Senator McLachlan) who has piloted the bill through the Senate has at all times been most courteous and considerate, and has never hesitated to give the fullest information on all subjects, even to those who frere, for the time being, opposed to him. He is a colleague of mine from South Australia, and, therefore, it is perhaps not fitting for me to praise him too highly, but I feel that I must express my personal' appreciation, and that of my party, for his assistance to all honorable senators during the tariff debate. To the customs officers who assisted the Minister, the best thanks of the Senate are due, as also to the Hansard staff, and those associated with them in the" compilation of the permanent record of proceedings. The manner in which the Senate has dealt with this tariff schedule has enormously increased its prestige. It has silenced many critics who formerly looked upon the Senate as a replica of its master's voice in another place.

speech.para: I now desire to refer to the negotiations in which the Resident Minister in London (Mr. Bruce) is at present engaged on behalf of the Australian Government with respect to the restric tion of wheat-producing acreage. A number of contradictory newspaper reports have been published in Australia during the last two or three weeks from which it is difficult to gather the actual lines upon which the World Economic Conference is proceeding. I realize that the Government is in an extremely delicate position, and I am not going to criticize the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Pearce) for tha meagre nature of the information conveyed to honorable senators. But I desire to utter a warning to the Government because this is the last opportunity that we shall have, at least for a brief period, to speak on behalf of the respective States and of the wheat-grower* of Australia generally, as to the consequences which may accrue from the adoption of an agreement which may not be considered in every detail. In this respect I call to my assistance no less a personage than the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Hawker), a former Minister in the present Government. In discussing the proposals to limit the export of wheat from Australia, at a pleasant Sunday afternoon gathering held in Maughan Church, in Adelaide, on Sunday last, Mr. Hawker made the following declaration :-

quote.para: To ask Australia to join in a conspiracy to stint the hungry so that she and other wheat-exporting countries may obtain higher prices for their wheat from people -who are already well fed seems to me to be entirely wrong in principle.

speech.para: I agree with Mr. Hawker. The adoption of such a proposal would mean stinting the hungry, not only in other countries, but also in Australia unless some mean* is provided to compensate the farmers in this country for the wheat they would not be permitted to sell without imposing an additional burden on the consumers of bread in Australia. I was perturbed in reading a paragraph in the Canberra Times this morning, in which it is suggested that Canada favours a restriction of wheat acreage and wheat export. I do not believe in a restriction of acreage or df export, but according to the paragraph in the newspaper mentioned, it is proposed to overcome this difficulty by an international plan. The individual grower would be under no restriction as regards acreage and production, but the maximum quantity he could market from any crop would he fixed and the balance would be left entirely on his hands. That may appeal to Canadian growers. I have some knowledge of the conditions existing in the wheat-growing areas of Australia, and the idea of leaving marketable wheat on the hands of the average Australian farmer is anathema to me. In the. Commonwealth we have two kinds of wheat-growing districts. We have safe districts where farmers can produce wheat almost any season because the rainfall, soil and other natural conditions are admirably suited for its production. In other districts tremendous areas have been developed at great expense by State governments concerned, where rainfall is doubtful, and where other important factors enter into consideration. In these districts frequent failures are experienced in the growing of cereals. I ask the Government that all these matters shall lie seriously considered. In South Australia we have what is known as the fringe country, comprising 13,000,000 acres of land which produces probably one crop in three years. On Eyre's Peninsula, which has been described as South Australia's new province, there is a tremendous area of land which has been developed at great expense to the State, but where the rainfall and other conditions are such that periodical failures occur; If restrictions are to be imposed full consideration must be given to all these factors and their possible influence upon the finances of not only individual farmers, but also the State governments concerned. I urge that the most serious consideration be given to the matter before any final agreement is entered into by the Resident Minister in London on behalf of the Government. I recall our unhappy experience under the Ottawa agreement, which this Parliament was practically forced to ratify. I do not wish a similar set. of conditions to occur so that there shall be any restriction on the planting of wheat or of its export from Australia.

speech.para: I understand that the right honorable the Leader of the Government (Mr. Lyons) has returned to Canberra from Sydney, and I should like to know if the Leader of the Senate (Senator Pearce) ha3 any information to give with regard to the recent application by the Blue Star line of steamers to share the Australian overseas trade with vessels included in the Overseas Transport Association, about which there has been some argument of late. The addition of vessels of the Blue Star line to that trade will, I believe, be of material benefit to our primary producers; but, judging by reports that have appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald^ the Labor Daily, and. other 'newspapers, it would seem that the shipping companies connected with 'the overseas- shipping ring, have formed what may be called a mercantile KuKluxKlan. They object to. ships belonging to other companies taking part in the trade, because of the possibility of rebates in freights being demanded. Every consideration should be given to the proposal made by the Blue Star line for permission to enter the 'magic circle' that has been built around Australia's oversea trade. I understand that a deputation representing the Blue Star line interests will wait on the Prime Minister on Tuesday next, and I should like to know if the Loader of the Senate can indicate what the Government proposes to do in this matter.

talk.start.para: . - I thank my leader (Senator Pearce), the Deputy Leader of the Labour party (Senator O'Halloran), the Leader of the Country party (Senator Johnston), and Senator Dunn for all the kind things which they have said about me. I agree with my leader, whose expression of opinion was echoed by Senator O'Halloran, that the examination by honorable senators of the many tariff items was very minute indeed - far too much so for my comfort, I may say, for while I prepared myself for the criticism which I expected would be directed against certain of the items, and tried to anticipate the various heads under which discussion would develop, I overlooked the possibility of a close examination of the 1921-30 tariff rates. If, therefore, I stumbled over some of the fences, I am sure that honorable senators will forgive me. This was my first experience of tariff-making. Doubtless, honorable senators will expect me to say that I hope it will be my last, but I am afraid that I must disappoint them. At the moment I have no such wish. I desire to thank the Chairman of Committees (Senator Herbert Hays) and the Clerk and ClerkAssistant, who were always anxious to helD me,, and by their advice, greatly facilitated the passage of the tariff.

speech.para: I also wish to thank those officers of the Customs Department who, for the last seven weeks, have been at my beck and call, and have never through any fault of their own failed me in any respect. I should like honorable senators to realize how extremely grateful I am for the consideration that they have extended to me, as well as for having allowed to pass without debate, certain items upon which I had prepared magnificent orations.

Senator Sir GEORGEPEARCE (Western Australia - Minister for Defence) [6.1]. - I assure Senator O'Halloran that the Government will watch most closely every step that is taken in connexion with the wheat question, recognizing as it does' that the well-being of Australia is largely wrapped up with that' of the wheat industry. A substantial rise in the price of wheat would help the industry, and we should not be backward in accepting any reasonable scheme that would attain that end.

Senator Dunnhas referred to the application of the Blue Star Line' for admission to membership of the Australian Oversea Transport Association, which is a loose confederation of the various shipping companies that are engaged in overseas transport to and from Australia. During the regime of the Scullin Administration, this body was given some sort of recognition by an alteration of the Australian Industries Preservation Act and a shipping committee was set up. The question of the Blue Star Line being admitted to membership of the association is one, not for the Government, but for the association itself.

talk.start.para: - Why, then, is a deputation from the Blue Star Line to interview the Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) on Tuesday?

- So far as I understand the position, there has merely been an intimation to the Government by the Blue Star Line, that it has made the request that it be permitted to become a member of the association. If that permission were refused, the necessity for action on the part of the Government might arise, but so far no such action is called for.

speech.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hoa. P. J. Lynch). - It is worth while to have lived through the last six weeks of strongly contrasting viewpoints, and the clashing of opinions, and to arrive at the stage at which the dominant note is harmony of the best type. That should be the position in a free democracy; because it must be recognized that there are as many opinions held in regard to the proper control and government of a country as there are brands of tea. So long as one generously acknowledges the right of one's fellows' to hold a different opinion with freedom equal to one's own, so long will the spirit of goodwill, tact, and tolerance prevail.

I heartily agree with all that has been said concerning the conduct of the business of the Senate, but disclaim any right to share in the praise that has been bestowed. I have lived in the reflection of the light shed by the Chairman of Committees, upon whose shoulders has rested the major portion of the work. For a beginner, the honorable gentleman has discharged his duties with courtesy and uncommon efficiency, and has given satisfaction to all interests, even when tha flashpoint has been most brilliant. Snob an achievement betokens the possession of rare qualities.

I have not had the experience of the Leader of the Senate, but I can say that the manner in which the tariff has been handled on the present occasion compares more than favorably with the circumstances that have attended the passage of any previous tariff with which I have had the privilege of being associated. The whole' tariff, and not a part of it only, was dealt with, and linked up with it were considerations affecting affairs in other parts of the Empire, whereas former tariffs have involved only the less complex aspect of Australian affairs. Needless to say, that has made the work of handling this tariff much more arduous and painstaking.

The officers of the Senate have, as usual, fulfilled expectations by having performed their duties with efficiency, courtesy, and conscientious endeavour. In that, they have achieved the double purpose of having satisfied themselves, and, at the same time, harmonized the opposing views of honorable senators. I wish honorable senators the best that fortune can place in their hands.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
